comments.commentBody: That was a snarky reply. America has had genocide against Native American tribes and then coopted their names for athletic teams. America has colleges built with slave labor and the incomes from slave labor based enterprises. Really no room for smugness.
Maybe an Ohio State man could do a better job than a " Michigan Man".
One more point: millions of cable subscribers are forced to pay for ESPN even though they NEVER watch it! What a country.
No one in the SEC cares, sadly. And ESPN drives a culture where winning is the only thing.

The Ivy League, once the citadel of college football, decided generations ago that big-time football and high academic standards were like oil and water.

When Notre Dame's president Theodore Hesburgh (in the 1950's) asked the president of Princeton how Notre Dame could achieve the academic excellence of Princeton the response was clear and direct: "Fire your football coach."

It's time for the rest of the country to catch up with the Ivy League. Higher education should be about education not national football championships.

As some commenters implicitly suggest, today's plunge in commodities prices for west Texas and worldwide crude may be the result of traders piling on at the tail end of a longer term price decline. If that is the primary explanation for the decline, it is likely the decline is over or nearly over.

However, prices of the commodity and stocks of oil company and drillers peaked in the second quarter and have been declining since. What is significant about this week's price activity in crude is that it was accompanied by significant declines in interest rates of US Treasury securities, suggesting that a flight to the safety of government paper is underway and, that, perhaps, diminished demand for oil coupled with declining retail pump prices may be jeopardizing the financing structures of both large and small producers as well as signalling potentially deflationary prices economy wide.

Since July, the Crude Oil Trading Index closed end fund has declined nearly 37%, and lenders to these producers tend to get antsy if the value of collateral declines. The very last thing the economy needs now are deflationary prices and a credit bust in the oil fields if lenders decide to call in more collateral from these producers.

Not sure why I read this article except I cannot understand at all the stress on football at this university. Financially, with in-state tuition it was a good deal for a good education, so my kids attended.

But the kids went there for reasons totally unrelated to sports as did a very large number of the students there. I don't know if they ever went to a game; we were not rich; the kids earned their optional spending money, and tickets were expensive. As adults they have moved on, don't go to games or wear school sweatshirts. As I sacrificed. and paid full tuition, I don't think they 'owe' the place more money.

So my two cents. U of M is a corporation with a corporate existence mainly interested in perpetuating itself. thus the incessant fund raising, showy athletics and lots of whoop it up PR. All that best of the best stuff.
In the meantime there are good academics there and people interested in academic pursuits. And on that side a grantsmanship game that is also run for the benefit of the school's income.

I am not at all sure how benefit to the actual students is factored into all of this. My observation is that the kids are pretty much on their own to get through successfully and football has nothing to do with that. So be it. This is all a distraction.

Should not university presidents respond to the university's mission:  education of its students and not respond, or be responsbile to, the irresponsible, immature fan base?  Memo to university presidents and governing boards: stand up and be counted.  Do the right thing.
Martin, that's secondary.  Try I CAN'T SLEEP A WINK.  Of course, WEEKEND WARRIORS is tertiary, unless you cross it with STORING.
What the heck is 'entrepreneurship"?  Hustling grant money? If so what percentage of  the grad students doing the work end up with academic jobs in the area of research?  Corporate jobs?

That's a low blow.  And what of the casualty counts of Southeast Asians in the USA's Vietnam War (3-4000,000) or  of Iraqis in its more recent Bush-Cheney led invasion of Iraq (over 1,000,000).  But Americans don't like to acknowledge their own genocidal actions, of which there's a very long history.  And a long history of denial.

I can't disprove this comment, but it doesn't ring true to me based on my anecdotal experience. By random chance, I had two classes with prominent basketball players during my time at U-M, one of which was a French language class. There's no faking it in a language class. You either know it or you don't and I can say this particular player was as prepared as any other student in the class when called on by the instructor. The other player was in a history seminar and when he showed up unprepared one week, the instructor asked him to just leave and not bother returning until he was prepared and ready to contribute to the discussion. I don't think the instructor even had any idea who he was (hint: Fab Five?) The player returned the next week and was reasonably prepared each class thereafter.
That said, I recognize there have been some difficult issues surrounding athletics (hint again: Fab Five). I was dismayed when shortly after I graduated, U-M started using the "block M" in place of the school seal in all of its communications. That sent a unfortunate message in my view. But in all fairness, none of the current issues at U-M suggest that athletics have substantially compromised the academic integrity of the school, particularly when compared to other universities with major sports programs. If anything, this soul-searching in the absence of a major scandal suggests that U-M still very much has its soul.
LOL... yes. Perhaps "communications" would have been a more appropriate choice.

when I was in Ann Arbor in the 1970's it was not unlikely to run into school athletes that's were going for a degree in Engineering, Medicine or some other strenuous program. I feel that today there is no room for someone like that today. They can't compete against the kids that are there to get onto a professional team, or at least very few that can. I just think in the long run it be be better if we just allowed these kids to be paid for their abilities and allow each University to field a semi-professional team.  Then you can separate out the kids who want to pursue professional athletics rom the kids who just want to participate in sport. It would also keep schools from cheating and saying they have student athletes when really there just a bunch really good professionals highly under paid.

John, that's an ignorant comment. Ask any professor at any university what they think of the department in their same field at Michigan and you'll almost certainly hear positive things. This is a school that greatly enjoys its athletic success on Saturdays, but also enjoys considerable academic success the other six days of the week.

There are well over 400,000 alumni. You don't speak for anybody except yourself. I tend to be concerned with commenting on football stories relative to a football article, which this is. Should the Times decide to report on Michigan academics, I comment on academics at that time. Your conclusion about compensation is nonsensical.
I am not sure what a 'tedious' academic is, but at least it likely has something to do with the purpose of a university: education.

I wholeheartedly agree with your sentiment James. If the NBA and NFL had any ethos at all, they'd set up a minor league system in which any athlete that comes out of high school with above average talent can make their mark in a minor league after a few years and then go to the big league. The overwhelming majority would not make it to the big league but would then get a scholarship to attend whatever higher education institution they wanted. Those who do go on to the big leagues will have no problem financing their own college education, assuming they wanted one at that time.

Yes, there'd be all kinds of issues with this concept, but it would recognize that a student is a student first.

But, alas, we'll never see this happen. Craving for our Alma mater to beat the other college in football and basketball is simply too woven into the American fabric. I'm preaching heresy.

College football cannot be cleaned up until the athletic scholarship is banned.

I would also suggest reinstitution the Junior Varsity squad system as mandatory to let Freshmen and Sophomores play on a limited basis while completing at least 2 years of college before playing varsity football.

As a Michigan and Stanford alumnus I have a deep enthusiasm for their many and various teams' success, but stepping back from my own version of "school spirit", it is easy to see that it all comes from tradition and acculturation. Why shouldn't students and alumni be just as excited if all athletic scholarships were abolished and instead given for academic excellence and financial need? Each year, each school would assemble its walk-ons in every sport and there would be tremendous added excitement from that process and the thrill of numerous upsets and unexpected outcomes. Why shouldn't Slippery Rock win the National Championship in an upset studded year because they benefited from the randomness of walk-ons? Surely anyone can see the elaborate ritual of "recruiting" and "full rides" is a farce with no connection to the mission of ANY university. Let the NFL and NBA fund their own minor leagues instead of corrupting college sports with money. Let the athletes who currently bemoan studying and desire salaries for their sport participation migrate to those minor leagues.
The NCAA and its relationship to the two big sports has slowly drifted far off course over decades of lapping up the money.

If you do not wish to inhale drug and chemical-laden vapors, then I suggest you find another planet.

The biggest problems with cars is the self-righteousness of drivers are convinced they are 100% harmless and should be allowed to be used anywhere with impunity.

If you drive a car and I don't, do I have the right to insist you be banned from driving because I don't want to inhale the chemical-laden vapors it produces?

Realistically, the health effects of inhaling second-hand e cigarette vapor are trivial. They just don't produce it unless the vaper is actually inhaling, whereas a cigarette is constantly emitting sidestream smoke.

People here the word "cigarette" and get scared. I'd be much more concerned about that bus that's passing by, pumping out fine particulates.

I completely agree that if one is going to consume nicotine, that an e-cigarette is highly likely to be a less harmful way to do so than an ordinary cigarette. However, e-cigarettes and consumption in nicotine in general is not harmless, and as such similar regulatory mechanisms need to exist to that which we already have for cigarettes.

The biggest problem with e-cigarettes is the self-righteousness of users who are convinced they are 100% harmless and should be allowed to be used anywhere with impunity. I do not wish to inhale anyone's drug and chemical laden smoke or vapors regardless of whether one is "less harmful" than the other.

Robert Maynard Hutchins was the President of the Chicago at the time (previously being the youngest dean of Yale law school).  He had to run Alonzo Stagg out as football coach and then suffer a few years of bad teams before killing the program (Stagg's OC was head coach and invented the man-in motion offense, which he taught to Halas).  Hutchins was also the President when Chicago was voted the best University in America.  His response was "We're not very good but we're the best around."  He was also known for denouncing economics as pseudo-science, advocating for trade/vocational schooling in the k-12 programs and the Great Books program.
Fortunately, Michigan's athletic department is self-sustaining, so no tuition or state money is used to pay coaches.  However, this is no the case with most schools.

I don't know about a fool, but maybe a dreamer.

Jim Harbaugh wants to win a Super Bowl to match his competitive brother John. His wife wants to stay in the Bay area. He enjoys the huge NFL salary that the 49ers and soon to be employer, Oakland Raiders, are willing to pay him. Most importantly, he would love to stick it to the 49ers, turn around the moribund Raiders and leading them to the Super Bowl. The Raiders have some talent. Now, they just need an inspirational leader and guy who can really coach.

John Harbaugh has said "No thanks" on a number of occasions and he also enjoys the NFL money. Maybe a guy like Les Miles, a true "Michigan Man, " would be a good fit. However, there are no 5 star players and talent is disappearing rapidly as the coaching carousel continues.

I honestly think that Rich Rod for all the punishment he took, actually was leading the team towards success in 21st century football. The problem was that he couldn't execute his 4 year plan which showed some improvement each year after a disastrous beginning. He started with a team lacking in serious talent and future commitments. He was fired before his plan came to fruition. Hoke later won the Sugar Bowl with Rich Rod's players. However, the needed coaching didn't follow and despite being a "Michigan man," he did not succeed.

Whoever is the next coach, has a really tough road ahead. Michigan, welcome to Brown athletics! UM is now athletically and academically approaching the Ivy League.

While Rodriguez now enjoys success at Arizona, at Michigan, he was a poor fit and got the program in quite a bit of trouble with NCAA sanctions. He was rightfully maligned for more than bucking tradition.

I grew up in Ann Arbor through the third grade and returned there from NYC for college (class of '90) largely based on the deep affection I had built for Michigan football and the discovery that it was a really good school too. I bled and still trickle maize and blue. We spent hours in our yards pretending to be Rick Leach and Anthony Carter. We ended every music class in elementary school singing "The Victors." We have hands down the coolest helmets in football (the only thing Mr. Brandon seemingly didn't touch) and winning the national championship in 1997 was a moment of immense satisfaction.

What ails Michigan is the product on the field. We have not attracted the same level of talent as we once did and when we do for some reason our coaches can't mold them to perform at the highest level. All that can change with the right leadership and the right coaches. That is all the new president needs to understand.

The article doesn't mention it and it pains me greatly to say it but the previous coach, Rich Rodriguez, who was properly maligned for bucking tradition and not being a Michigan man, is actually doing a superb job here in Tucson with an Arizona team that consistently overachieved this year with less talent than Michigan. Go figure.

With any luck, a man named Harbaugh (either one is fine with me) will leave the NFL, put on his cape and save the day in Ann Arbor and all the pain and misery of this season will be long forgotten.

Am I a fool? Yes. But, go blue.

R. WIll, That is the point. Football funding has little to do with overall university funding. Donors are not giving to schools because of football, and losing football funds would mean little to overall education and nothing to research at Michigan.

Don't misunderstand. Michigan is clearly one of the world's elite academic institutions, and sports can be an important part of character education. If Michigan can balance both, great, but let's not pretend sports fund more than they do.

I am an auto worker's son and the first person in a very large Detroit area extended family to attend college. I want to say thanks to the state of Michigan and the University of Michigan for providing me with an excellent public education and preparation for earning a good living over the last 32 years as a civil engineer.

So we are not in the top ten of football, at least we are in the top ten in engineering. I can handle the ups and downs of athletic success.

GO BLUE!
nothing. they have no academic qualifications to fall back on if they don't make it in the NFL or CFL.....

Bruce Wrobel was the single reason football came back to MIT in 1978. Without him there would not have been a team and there still might not be one. In addition to being an solid quarterback (he was recruited by several Ivy League schools but decided to go to MIT) he was also a standout wrestler in college. Last weekends WSJ had a good front-page story on the how football came back to MIT: http://online.wsj.com/articles/how-players-at-mit-engineered-a-football-...
